reviewText:
Pros:
-Damn fun to play and fly around. I chose to start as a trader, and it's really easy for me to take on 20 missions at once and keep getting missions as I fly around completing them.
-The descriptions and the detail put into it is great.
-The idea of it being open-sourced and available to modify is great. I haven't tried it yet though.

Cons:
-A bit of a confusing interface, and limited controls. When one of my fleet ships was disabled, I couldn't figure out how to repair it for a couple of minutes. I ha to beat off around 7-8 pirate attacks while I was trying to figure it out. A lot of those more hidden mechanics could be more obvious.
-It's very confusing on what is mounted onto your ship, what isn't, and how each module affects the ship stats. I largely have only bought ships and put an extra cargo area on them. I'd reccomend putting a seperate window on the right side that shows the ship slots, and as you change modules, it also displays the changes in stats.
-The game seems (so far) pretty limited to small fights and trading. It would be neat to have more space in between planets, allowing for ambush attacks and whatnot instead of jumping into a sector and immediately knowing whether there are enemies there or not. Things happen incredibly fast, and most of the time I die before I even knew I was taking significant damage.
-After the short tutorial storyline, apart from a couple of things happening in the galaxy, I haven't been able to find the main stroryline again. Some subtle hints as to where it is would be nice.
-Please, give me more control over my fleet's ships. I have had so many times where we're extremely far away from a battle, yet one of my ships insists on firing it's missiles and wasting credits.

Conclusion: I hope that this is not the end of development for this game. It feels complete, yet still missing a lot of potential. If this was paid, I wouldn't reccomend people get it unless it's extremely cheap, but as it's free to play, I would say that there's no harm in trying it out.

The game has lots of potential but holy ♥♥♥♥ does it need work. Merchant/Neutral AI are absolute c**ts. They blow the ♥♥♥♥ out of any hostile ship -- should be obvious right? Shouldn't be bad? Well it's real ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ annoying that this grind-fest of a game forces me to watch some little pissant cargo ship knock out that last little bit of health on a fine pirate ship I just wasted five minutes disabling. Five feet from getting onboard and looting, or capturing the ship a little ♥♥♥♥er like that ruins it.

It's great for modding, I'm damn well going to be adding my own little tweeks so this stops happening. I'd love to see more missions... maybe conquering planets, or colonizing them. Maybe building your own station/shipyards. Ordering your fleet to do supply runs for you to remove the grind.

Anyway, aside from grinding and some annoying as f**k AI this is a pretty cool game

reviewText:
So far its a very nice even if small game:

You start choosing naming your character, choosing your first ship wich will determine your role for quite some time (ship are expensive) and then pay off your debt of 450 000 credit, after this be free to choose your path

Be a bounty hunter, a merchant, a pirate, a commander of your own fleet, some event happens to pop up sometime so it doesn't feel like nothing happens in the game lore history

The game is good to chill out, gameplay is simple and it save every time you land on a planet, good for casual gamer or too kill some time

The AI is rather usefull, you will use them often until you buy (or manage to board) a bigger ship, random passing by ship can give you some fuel for 1 jump when there is no planet to land and refuel, they repair your ship so you can move again and even take on pirate on sight

I chose, to begin with, a trader. Followed the advice on one of the discussions here, and 3 hours later I had a small fleet of 4 ships.
Not exactly ground-breaking graphics or anything special. Just a nice, relaxing space game where I can be in full control of how I want to play.

Being free, and virtually invisible in HD space, it's hard to find a reason NOT to try it at least.

reviewText:
Product received for free

Endless Sky is kinda like if EV Nova was a bit too fast paced, focused heavily on having a fleet rather than your warship doing the work, and loaded the pirates up with heavy weaponry on basically every pirate ship.

Otherwise it's very similar. Same grind to earn money/reputation, same obscure way to start plot(s), same tendency to sort of abruptly murder the player.

I'll be coming back to the game once the modders get their teeth into it, hopefully adding something like the railguns from EV Nova (my favorite weapon, sadly missing here). For now, I'd say wait til further in development.

reviewText:
The bottom line of this review is this: THIS GAME IS NOT EV NOVA. If you want to play EV Nova, GO PLAY EV NOVA - to this day, there is no suitable replacement for the original Escape Velocity games, and although Endless Sky comes close mechanically, it falls short atmospherically. The original EV games still hold up so if you are like me, with a hankering for that old EV feeling, you might as well just go play one of the originals.

[EDIT: I feel like I should just amend my review to say that Sunless Sea is a great modern game which is mechanically (if not thematically) similar to EV Nova and does a great job with atmosphere and writing, just with boats instead of space]

I was dying to play some EV Nova so I thought I'd try this game. It is a very accurate clone of many of the aspects of the Escape Velocity series, right down to the button labels and some ship designs, but somehow it doesn't all come together. Combat in Endless Sky isn't something you engage in, it's just something that seems to -happen- and then you either die or your enemies die. Every time I engaged in combat it felt totally binary, as if nothing i did tactically would alter my chances of win/loss. The game seriously needs to have its combat stats rebalanced to slow things down (esp. in the early game) and allow more drawn-out tactical encounters.

I did very much appreciate some of the improvements to the map/mission/trading interfaces, they make buy-low-sell-high a piece of cake with their profit/loss tracker. BUT, after several hours I actually found this detracted from one of the things I liked about Escape Velocity - the writing. It was so easy to fall into a trading groove that I actually found myself not even glancing at the planet and spaceport descriptions, and I found that after 12 hours I hadn't absorbed any of the flavor of the universe. Every planet became reduced to a set of pricing data. It just turns into a game of how-can-i-make-these-numbers-bigger.

My recommendation to other gamers is that instead of playing this game, you just find a copy of EV and play that. My recommendation to the developer of this game is to find a way to slow combat down and recapture the tension of EV (where did escape pods / hardmode go?).

reviewText:
it is free so cant complain i guess, seems like its not really finished. basically at teh begining you get to pick from 3 ships, if you dont pick the cargo ship you lose or you will be slow at making money you wont want to play.

pros:
its free and you might get a day worth of play out it

you can have a fleet of ships?

cons:
fighting is stupid, pretty much whoever has the better ships wins, which you might be thinking that makes sense, but there arent that many ships and you dont have many options on customizing your ship.

so lack of ships/items for ships. so you want a fast ship? well not really going to happen. you want a ship with lots of guns? well not really going to happen. best ship has 6 turrets and i think 2 maybe 4 guns, turrets auto aim, guns only fire frontwards, which combat isnt that well done so i usually took out he guns and added more shields. oh you want a ship with tons of shields? well doesnt seem to help much. if it was like skyranger and over time ships/ship items got better game would improve a bunch. not sure what i should do with 1000 million nothing to spend it on.

trade system is lacking, if you did trade runs you would never mke any money, have to do missions, which is fine  just random and boring after the 1000th time seeing your ship spin in circles over and over and over again.  looting pirates will make you more money than you ever dreamed of if you do it right and can get past the stupid fighting/controls.

looting ships or being a pirate is crap too, most of the time you try to disable a ship so you can loot it and the ai blows it, about 99.9% of the time. have to almost be alone against the other ship but then no point to a fleet, no hey fleet just disable them and go to next target so we can make money option!!!!! also not sure how you would be a pirate, ships move to fast to really target one thats not hostile, like the average merchant ship. plus one would think that you might find better systems on the pirate ships, since they do way better against you for what they have, but no. dont think i ever used any off of a ship except to sell.

story line. seen some reviews ssaying story line is awesome. from what i have seen you get special missions randomly from going to space ports. only problem is i have only seen 4 missions and dont think any of them are the main story line, and there is no telling where it begins. also ships randomly says stuff, like join the navy see the universe. havent been able to join any faction, or even see really any factions fighting besides pirates.

also the way ships move they have to come to complete stop the spin in a circle a couple of times before landing or hyperjumping. very annoying after a while.

but for a free game its worth every penny!!

reviewText: I really wanted to like this game. I first want to just say that I give the developer props for trying but unfortunately, the game just isn't for me. I don't understand the complaints about the visuals but I do unserstand the complaints about the controls. They're a little clunky and slow. I would generally be able to look over that if the game brought more to the table but unfortunately it just doesn't. My biggest issue is the cost of mortgage and rewards from missions. Rarely does the reward for the mission meet the cost of mortgage and leave enough left over to make decent money. Not only that, but the majority of missions are cargo based regardless of your ship type. As a fighter, I found that I often wouldn't have enough space whatsoever for many missions. That directly plays into the rewards. Granted, as was brought out to me, fighters are best for working at enemy ships. Overall, I have to say that this game isn't worth it for me, but, you may feel otherwise. Try it out.

Trading isn't very complicated and let me get a feel for how ships fly

Pirates will spawn kill you along with spontainiously spawning ontop of you whenever they seemingly feel like it.

Majority of the enemies you run into will basically immediately kill you or disable you and from that point they will board you or someone else will come distract them to which point I've been unable to discover how to get my ship moving again as no one comes in range and I have to load or restart.

Enemies boarding seems majorly pointless anyway as it seems they just kill you off regardless and I have to load a save or restart.

Progression is painstakingly slow if you want to trade, slightly faster if you do missions but still very very slow.


My Experience with escourting:

Progress moves along much much faster than trading.

Near implausible to capture pirates as anyone you're escourting will just light up the already low health ship with turrets nearly immediately killing them

Getting spawnkilled and stomped on by literally everything still

At least I can run away faster than a cargo barge.

reviewText:
Beyond what is a very competent EV Nova clone, with trading, combat etc. I never felt like I was playing a game. You will be pressing two key an awful lot and these keys almost define the gameplay.

Lets say you are doing a trade run. You use the map to plot a course and leave the station. To get across space, on a journey of what could be many, many jumps you only need two keys!

J to jump
L to land

And that's it. You don't have to steer, you don't have to brake. When you press those keys the autopilot flies the ship for you. I never saw a lot of combat but was attacked on a couple of occasions by pirates. Fortunately my shields and armour held. But on those two occasions the only keys I pressed were J and L.

Oh, almost forgot. The game has almost no sound assets at all. No music and precious little effects. You can hear your thrusters and gunfire but the effects are entirely underwhelming.

reviewText:
I'm not going to go light on this game just because it's free. It's on Steam so it's  open to criticism.

Basically, this game suffers the same weaknesses as almost all other Github games. It was developed in an echochamber by entitled coder(s) with apparently little playtesting or outside player input, and the end result is a bunch of code that doesn't interact well. Lots of mechanics work against each other, and the game is barely playable as a result.

The problem with Github is that the average Github coder is a self-proclaimed creator who neither plays the game he helps create or listens to player input. The command structure is basic and not even the person who approves code merges bothers to playtest what he approves. As a result, Github games are always going to be barely playable messes. I liken Github to Communism: Wonderful in theory, completely dysfunctional and prone to failure in reality.

>all enemies will shoot the player craft into disabled mode, but not destroy purposefully
>pirates are completely ineffectual, random spawn mob enemies that die without accomplishment
>there is no difference between police and military, all government vessels are massive warships
>pirates only seek to disable other ships, nearly all other ships destroy pirates without attempting to loot
>the random ship spawn mechanic is not remotely balanced

Wouldn't play if it wasn't free, and it's unfinished Github fodder that doesn't belong on Steam.

reviewText:
Tried traveling from area to area, but without an actual tutorial on where and how to do things there was barely anyway to find these new zones/planets that ARE NOT connected on the map.

Extremely frustrating even just trying to help out the first person in the dialog in the first place.

This game seems like you need a book on how to play it just to play the damn thing.

The hyperspace feature is nice, but if you're going to go out and adventure you need to make it POSSIBLE to find these other areas, didn't even get to do the 2nd mission just after helping the retired space traveler.

Would LOVE to spend more time into figuring out how to play this game, but when there's nothing CLEAR ENOUGH on where and how to play it there is literally no point and that's why I cannot even stand to recommend this game to anybody.

Would rather move my ship around by mouse and click rather than keyboard arrows and just simply use the regular firing buttons.

For quite some time I spent just sitting there hoping my ship would just eventually run into the next planet or system, but it just kept flying through many many other stars and says I cannot simply hyperspace to everything so how the HELL do I get to the places?    Follow the yellow brick road that all the other planets are connected to?

Cause that REALLY helped, not, I kept following each and every one that the lines are connected to on the map and all we ever did was end up finding more pirates.   The hyperspace feature wouldn't stop going between the same places I've already found multiple times.


WAY TOO TEDIOUS of a game.    If I ever have to play something this aggravating again without a GOOD & CLEAR tutorial I'd rather burn my computer then dismantle it.

reviewText: I was a huge fan of Escape Velocity back when it came out, so playing this game is a huge nostalgia trip for me. I've played a few other games inspired by EV, but this is the first one I've actually liked. It captures the feel and mechanics in a way that very closely resembles my memories of EV. There are some minor differences, but nothing that really diminishes from the experience for me. In fact, some changes (e.g. loans/mortgages, being able to see what goods trade for in other systems, etc.) add to the experience. The game is free, open source, and (in my opinion) very enjoyable. If you're an old fan of EV, or even if you never got to experience it, I think you should give it a shot.

reviewText:
I may or may not have bumped into this developer before, I feel, with another browser-based game set in the Star Trek universe (something along the lines of Broken Mirror). What kept me going in that game was the setting, less than the story; and in Endless Sky the story itself, after grinding for many hours, I have yet to encounter.

It's something I can play every now and again, given it's free, and don't have to put so much effort into. Unless you enjoy repetitive tasks which, despite minor details (the phrasing of one job as opposed to another; the fact some involve shipping things as opposed to escorting ships; destroying ships; sometimes capturing and selling them), equate to you going from one edge of the galaxy to the other for ca-chingas, then it's not for you.

I did enjoy the death-benefits component to this game.

And hey, it's free, it works, and it's a nice time waster.

It can get repetitive, that's why I set goals for myself.
My goal is simply, yet very time consuming: Amass a fleet so large, that my computer slows down by a lot. Bwahahaha!

Once you get the hang of it, you won't need to rely on missions for money, you'll just have to go around trading. If only making money in the millions was this easy. Hahaha!

Support the Navy?  Go crazy!

So happy I found this game (again). I played Escape Velocity a lot, then forgot about it -- only to now find Endless Sky on here. And it's on Github even, inviting others to help development. Absolutely love it!

As the only minor nagging point: I know the original dev of the game is against turning this into a multiplayer game (think I remember a comment of him to this effect). Personally, I'd love to see a small-scale multiplayer option though, say: a game session you can open that starts a universe with you and up to 3 of your friends. I believe this could add an entire new dimension to this game, without corrupting the original idea.

That said, even if this is never implemented (probably also not easy to do for a true free-to-play, open source game), I'd still happily recommend this game to anybody who enjoyed games like Privateer or Elite, and has a bit of a tolerance for comparably rudimentary, but functional graphics and design.

reviewText: This game is an excellent idea. However, right now it really lacks the polish that would make it fun. For instance, there's a reason Escape Velocity prevented you from making a hyperspace jump too close to the center of a system: without it this restriction, traffic moves too fast, and systems lack a sense of structure and atmosphere. Heck, even the asteroids move too fast. Combat is ridiculously fast, too. I can't learn anything from it, or even have fun running away from a much more powerful enemy and getting killed anyway—you just get zapped and die.\n\nI don't regret giving this a shot, and I think it has potential, but I don't recommend it right now. Modders will probably love it, though.

I was fairly disappointed by the poor performance of such a small game that should really be able to run flawlessly on just about anything.

This game has most of what I am looking for in a good game. However, there is a huge issue that I just can not ignore, witch is that lack of ships, planets, major missions, and upgrades. I have played Escape Velocity many times, and it too had the exact same problems, but it is not just that. After grinding for hours to get a good amount of income, I have found myself to a point at which doing anything other then trading was almost pointless. Other options to gain income never seemed to make sence with a good traiding rout.

The Job postings are not that fun to begin with, so realistically why would anyone do them if they serve no other purpose then that of a good trading rout. The space port missions are the only thing that allowed me to want to keep playing, as that is the only way to gain access to certen items, ships, etc. If there was something that Job postings could offer in the game that a trading rout could not, then that would deffinetly extend the enjoyment of playing this game longer.

Another thing that really just dose not have anything going for it is demanding tributes from planets. Other then the excitment of a bit of action in the game, demanding tributes of planets just dose not have a good enough reason to be done. I was hoping that there would be something more to it other then getting a few credits, but as it stands there really is no good reason to go through the effort of taking over a planet. Doing something like demanding tributes is just to repedative after awhile and the only reason I ever did it was to get rid of the hostile planets, so I could refuel on them. Like I stated before, it really serves no other purpose then that of a good trading rout.

Just to make a point here, I keep bringing up trading as the only real good source of income only because it is the fastest and easiest way to make money in the game. I have always liked this about these kinds of games, as it always seemed to give me a good feeling of acomplishment when I watched the credits increse after each trade as I keep adding to my fleet. I know that the options are there for different ways to gain credits, but the best way is through trading.

This game dose have a lot going for it, like the fleet that you can creat is nice added touch. All the ships that can be bought is deffinetly one of the main reasons I like this game (but a game could always have more). And the outfitting options on a ship seems like I can never get the best equipment (but the game could always have more of these too).

If you give this game a reason to have bigger ships, and better items then I will have a reason to keep playing and have fun doing it. However if there is no other reason to do any Jobs, or taking over planets aside from gaining credits, then after I get the best ship and items I can get, there will be no reason to contiue playing. This game is very fun to play, and I suggest anyone that has not played, to do so. I know this is a early access game so please do not take this post as anything other then helpful criticism.
Great open source game with hugh potential.

When I downloaded Endless Sky I wasn't expecting much of the game, I thought I would play it for a couple of hours and then forget about it but instead I discovered a real gem.

- The first thing that impressed me was the work behind the universe and history of the game. The developers did not create a new universe, they tried to imagine what the futur of mankind would look like if we were able to spread among the stars of our galaxy. You get to travel to real stars like Proxima Centauri, Vega, Aldebaran or Antares and there's more than a hundred worlds each with its own little background.

-  The best part was the main story :
What I really liked about the story is that you don't really choose to do the main quest. In fact you don't even start as the main character, you are just some random guy wandering trough the galaxy taking jobs and trading stuff. You encounter a few special quests here and there and then at some point the main story just comes at you and you get caught up in it, it took me several missions before understanding I had actually started the main quest.
I found the story to be quite rich ans really interesting, there is even some plot twists and it is pretty long, it took me about thirty hours to finish it. And once you are done there is still plenty to do (but no spoil).

- Last the ships and outfits, I was again impressed by the work behind it, I don't see this level of involvement very often in a free to play. There is a great variety of ships and outfits, each part of the galaxy sells different models of ships and unique types of outfits (better reactors, batteries, weapons, cooling systems, etc). It gives you a high level of customisation for your ship systems but it is also quite strategic since you have to deal with your energy consumption and heat production.

I recommend everyone to a least give it a try since it is free and as for me I look forward to any future update.
I'm looking forward to see how this game ends up. As it stands, it's a pretty good tribute to the EV games and I think it has the potential to be a lot better.

Endless Sky is a wonderful combination between those classic text RPGs that were a cross between a game and a novel, and updated, real-time intuitive controls. While the game is rather text heavy (It could REALLY use some cutscenes), the core game is great, and offers lots of freedom. Want to be a space pirate and take over ships? No problem! Want to be a trader, making a fortune travelling between planets? You got it! Want to be an explorer, mapping out the entire galaxy? Of course! This game doesn't really limit what you can do and what you can't do.

That being said, the game could use a little tidying up. Many times, I found myself jumping into a system, only to see a laserfight take place for virtually no reason, so I just jumped out without caring. Other times I got stuck and tried to contact a ship in order to leave. only to then realize I was contacting an attacker. Maybe some color system could differentiate between friend and foe? I dunno.

Still, this game is a blast, and considering it's free, I think it's definitely a fun little game to sink many hours into.
I would recommend this game to anyone who wanted to simulate being a captain of a ship, or people who are really into sci-fi. If you're looking for fantastic gameplay - this game may not be best suited for you. It is much more of an immersive experience, that's based on the world you explore and the way you interact with it.
I don't think I've ever had a free game suck me in like this, and I can't wait for more content to keep coming.

Endless Sky is a great game with cool artwork.It uses some real life photographs too which makesit all the more unique. This game isn't finished though so it's not the best it could be. The begining is kind of stressful but in a good way. Being in debt drives you forward and hooks you to the game. After that, your free. You transport colonists, do bulk and rush deliveries and even hunt pirates. There's also a great campaign hidden inside this game and it does not dissapoint. Not only do you get to experience large scale battles, you also do diplomacy missions and some escort missions as well. The Free Worlds campaign was my favorite part of the game and even after you finish its still fun to play the game.  I do wish that there were more missions to the campaign and even mini campaigns after where you make more cool technology and have systems join the Free Worlds diplomatically, especially the ones in the dirt belt. Also I'd like new Free Worlds Capital ships and even some light warships and interceptors too.  The campaign was hard but not too hard that it was frustrating. There should, however be more content to this game such as a dynamic economy, more ships, faction only ships (this includes pirates), a variety of new ship names, more campaigns such as a Syndicate or a  Republic campaign and that every hyperspace jump isn't a day. Also I think interceptors should have a power boost because currently its not even worth owning one. Theres a lot of great things in this game but theres always room to improve.

Have been looking for a game that I played durring my childhood for years. Just recently found out it was called Escape Velocity. Just wanted to figure out what it was called, and maybe play it again, but i figured seeings how it was so old, that wasn't going to be possible.

Then I found this game, and it is such a good tribute to that game, and has a lot of original charm.

This game its a space trading sim with a huge galaxy map. You can fight pirates, work for governments, or just have a fleet of cargo vessels follow you around as you amass a vast trade empire.

Getting a lot of money is kind of slow, if comparison to newer games, and younger gamers may not want to invest that much time in it. Fortunatly, the developer decided in their great wisdom to make the save file text. So if you want to go and give yourself a rediculous amout of money and buy tons of ships, you can. It does take away from the base gameplay, but sometimes its just fun flying around with a rediculous armada destroying everything in your path.

9.5/10 needs controller support and more commands for your fleet.
An excellent sandbox game for spacefarers. Controls take some getting used to and combat is tricky, but once you get some experience it is a fun and addicting game.

It's a nice little game, definitely worth the download. However, it's kind of buggy (mostly cause the main storyline is treated as a sidequest, and as such it is very easy to accidentally do something that messes it up and makes it uncontinuable, coupled by the merciless autosave (saves everything you do on a planet, so as soon as you land it saves anything you do automatically, meaning one foul up and your game is ruined.) and in early development, but it's pretty interesting and can keep you occupied for quite a bit.

I can do a pretty thorough pro's/con's list, but let me summarize why I like Escape Velocity (EV). It didn't DRAW you into the game. I can't stress how refreshing that is.

In my experience, games that DRAW you into them, are only good for people who don't have things to do in the real world. Even many of the so-called casual games require you not be distracted.

I got through high school on EV, and now that I run private business, have two kids, and very little free time, it's nice to find a game that actually lets you play without costing you in the real world.

In thirty minutes, I wrote this guide, made 4 million credits on my trade route, fed my daughter, talked to my son about a book he is reading, and cleaned portions of the kitchen. A productive morning. On top of that, if I can focus on the game, a quick switch of ships, and I can Join the Navy!" and blast some scum."

reviewText: I have been looking for an EV-like game for quite a long while. This is could be a very close twin of it. I've only played 3 hours of the game, but I see myself playing it for quite awhile. So far so good. If you have ever played Escape Velocity, then you need to download this now, and get your nostalgia on.\n\nKeep up the good work!

This game is free. This game does not seem like a free game now that I've played a bit. I would totally spend money on it. BUT I DON'T HAVE TO! The fact that this is only a beta version just makes me even more excited for what's to come.

Not to mention, the game is Open Source and allows for anybody to add new ships, weapons, missions or planets without even needing the source! Just check the description, there are links and stuff. I haven't clicked them yet, cuz I have my own projects to worry about, but you have a go at it.

Despite the way the economy works, as it is fixed for each planet, I found myself enjoying trading a lot more than other rpg's I've played, and, for once, the game didn't force me to carry an entire arsenal of weapons to avoid having a bad experience. I found this game extremely immersive, which is great inspiration for a sci-fi story, or something, if you're interested in writing.

However, one thing I cannot forgive this game for is it's writing. I mean, not in the whole game, mostly just one part in particular. Not even mostly, it's exactly just one part in particular. It's not necessarily a bad thing, nor did it ruin the game for me, it's just something I'm cherry picking because it really annoyed me at the time. SPOILERS IN THE NEXT BIT.

reviewText: This game is pretty fun.\nI recommend it, especially to those who, like me, have a computer that can't run big games, or to those who simply like this space trader-type game.\nKeep up the good work, devs! :)

Its free, It has great Depth, its fairly pretty to play, Its still being developed and updated.

Really do you need to know more just to pick it up and give it a shot? Ok well fine.

Pros:

Ship Customization: There is a fairly large variety of ships, all of which have thier own purposes, pro's and cons. I havn't played around with all of them yet, but its pretty apparent after a few hours that there is no single ship that does it all the best, there will always be another ship that does something better then your current ship, weather thats hauling freight, or blowing stuff up, or carrying passengers.

Equipment Customization: Each ship is customizable as far as the type of engines, weapons, and sub systems your ship has. There is great fun to be had trying to optimize your ship while maintaining a functional balance... or you can just say screw balance and desighn a way way overpowered ship in one class, that sucks in everything else.

Missions: All the various missions in the game are tailored to your ship/fleet. This is great starting out, as you wont have kill/escort" missions dropping on your head that honestly your lil tiny freighter has no hope of completeing. Have a bunch of freighters/transports? You'll get alot of those missions. Have a fleet of fighters? Get combat missions.

Combat: Combat is tough
recommended: but very enjoyable to watch/participate in. There can be massive fleet engagements
hoursPlayed: or slow duel's and dances.\n\nFreedom: You can pretty much play how you want
voteText: though some ways are easier then others. Can even conquer planets if you desire
helpfulPercent:
though the owning faction will be fairly upset with ou.

Cons:
Still in development: The Game has a few rough points
votesHelpful: and can be a bit stale occasionally. Hopefully this will get ironed out
votesTotal: even if it doesnt
votesFunny: heck
commentsCount: its free. I'd have easily dropped 5-10 bucks for this as is.\n\nCombat: Remember how i said combat could be hectic? Well it can also be unfair
column16: and its not very skill based. It usually comes down to who brought the most guns and the variety of guns involved. There is some ways to out skill combat
column17: but usually it comes down to luck
column18: and sheer fire power.\n\nStory: It is pretty lacking as of right now
column19: but the developer is working on this.\n\nEquipment: Although equipment is there
column20: there are few flat "upgrades" So there is little room for improvement of a ship once you have achieved the desire equipment setup. Most upgrades come from getting a different/better ship at this point. And once you have top tier everything
column21: any sense of progression pretty much stagnates.\n\nNo risk: This is more of a personal preference/grey area then an actual con. The game auto saves often
column22: so its very easy to go back to a previous save if things go south. Of course you could not reload
column23: but I personally have a hard time ignoring the temptation
column24: even though i wont a more perma death/risk like game."

reviewText:
Started as a captain, ended up as a commodore.
Great free game to play, clocked a good amount of hours flying, fighting and trading.

The Slate:
The game is still under development so the storylines are not yet complete, the onle playable one is the rebel/freeworlds story. There are a good amount of side quests for bounty hunting, escorting, and ferrying as well as trading.
The galaxy is pretty decent in size already, but I have high hopes on it growing and seeing more planets and factions.

Gameplay:
The game is very reminiscent of escape velocity, I noticed it is a lot easier to start of as a barge and make trade runs and buy more barges to increase your cargo. I really enjoyed the autopilot bits for landing and jumping to other systems, the auto firing I really appreciated since I wanted to be like those other ships and not fire every gun at the same time.

Wishes:
Faction specific ships, news, faction specific outfits, bigger galaxy, more factions, a steam workshop, junkyard systems, ship painting planets/stations. follow up quests or notes after helping people out, the ability to join a faction and fight as part of a fleet under a commander/work for corporations, after dominating a planet being able to shell out cash to upgrade infrastructure to add more ships, increase trade, increased population etc...

Cannot wait to see the game with more content in the future.
Confusing and lame\n

This seems like a fun game, but there is no tutorial. I must have spent at least a half in hour trying to figure out certain buttons, starting the game over to read everything and yet i didnt know what I was doing. The second mission I got was to escort a caravan, but I didnt know how to even fire a weapon I could clearly see that I had one but no were on the screen did it tell me how to use it. Sorry to the people who worked hard on the game but plz add a tutorial.

This game for a free game is excellent. Easy to get into, rewarding to play and most impresive is that it has a Story.

Sure, the combat mechanics could be a little better and there could be a Bounty hunter / reward for hunting Pirates. This does leave the easiest way to progress as becoming an intergalatic Eddie Stobart.

But Excellent.
This is a great game. For the 1980s. I enjoy it, don't get me wrong. But I would love if the game was an MMO.

Great! 4 out of 5!\n\nonly reason its not 5 out of 5 is cuz it's in the early development stages. sound effects aren't so good, and i wish coming out of hyperspace would stop you instantly in a more star wars-y fashion. but, I'm not saying this game should turn into a star wars-like game
my only complaints are pirates are over powered or, the lack of a difficulty setting. ship spins to jump despite already being in position to jump. despite that it's a good game

Love (or loved) this game! However i am stuck on a Free Worlds mission. I was making balance changes to the Firebird (raising price and shield cap) and whaddya know? Now enemys cant target my Firebird! Oh, and did i mention i cant target enemy Firebirds and MY ESCORT DREADNOUGHT CANT EITHER so it is slowly demolished and i attempt to kill the Firebirds and cant do it in time (as there are 4 or 5). How do i fix this?

My friend told me that this game was free and told me a brief overview of the game. So i was a little just blah about it. Deciding why not give it a try since it has high reviews....... I started it up and i find myself hours later staying up till one in the morning still playing the game. This game definitely has my 5 star approval!!!

Dull boring tedious there and back to see how far it is jump from FTL to the next pitstop to dump goods and passengers.... interface jumping back and forth in planet is painful and an entirely hokey slower than light speed maneuvering system to find a planet 'in system' to land on makes this game an entire waste of the 2.2 hours I spent on it...\n\nSorry.. but I expected more and to be honest the old 2d Elite was much more fun in its day....  I spent days going back and forth doing roughly the same - somehow this version of an old classic just put me off immediately

I keep battling with myself on whether this game is good or not. It's certainly got a little effort put into it - and it's free to boot. But on the flip side it's not a game anyone would have paid to play.

It's certainly addicting and plays heavy on the psychological urge to make the numbers grow - I played 8 hours of this yet I feel like I just started the game - but there's nothing I can honestly point out and say that was fun" about those 8 hours spent. Just a compelling urge to get back to it to make money and get better ships.

The combat is over nearly the instant it begins. If you get attacked the game is already decided as there's no actual time to think or react; before you can even visually see an enemy you often get shot from offscreen by a torpedo or rapidly hit by a fighter's beams in a way that just kills you inside 2-4 seconds of popping into the system. If you buy escort ships they can defend you
date: but the combat is over too fast for you (the human-controlled ship) to actually participate in any meaningful way.\n\nThere are quests that spice the game up a little bit with story if you stop off in some spaceports. They're not terribly different than other jobs you can get in actual function
recommended:
but you get a little story to go with the game.

The greater part of this game is just grabbing junk from one place and selling it in another place. Pirates show up at times and typically - if you're alone - they kill you before you can do anything about it.The game isn't brutal though. It autosaves everytime you land on a planet so if you die it's barely an inconvienence.

It's a free game so you can't really go wrong giving it a shot."

reviewText:
An unexpectedly AESOME game....

Reminds me of eve-online ... only single player

Also never realised how addictive pressing J/N/T/M buttons could be :P (J - jump, N - cycle target, T - talk to target, M - Universe map)

Oh and 100% free to play!

10/10 would press J/N/T/M again

Possibly the best free game I've played in quite a while. You can choose to go with a lot of different playstyles, either sticking to strictly legitimate (a long slow grind involving raising your in-game credit score ... no seriously), OOOOOR ... blow up pirates and run drugs through high security space.

I mean, the choice is obvious.

The map is pretty expansive. Not limitless, but large enough that getting from one end to the other will take a while, and probably end up being very expensive depending on how many ships and crew you have.

Definitely a game you can lose several hours in.

The storyline is fun to play, if you manage to actually get a storyline mission, and there is tons to explore.  do admit after a while when there isn`t enough to explore and rebels don`t seem to want to give you missions, it gets kind of boring, but they are adding more and more stuff so soon there will be much more replayability and it will probably be easy to access the story.\n\nOverall this game is great and its free so why not give it a try?

This is a simple and addictive game, if you don't mind the repetitively. Also, despite the simplicity, there are several ways you can go about playing the game. You can transport people and/or cargo or you can be a combatant and join a faction of your choosing.\n\nMy current and first choice was as a freight captain. Piloting a small, but fast Star Barge, I earned credits, albeit slowly, by flying small loads from one place to the other. Once I traded in the Star Barge for a Freighter, I was able to transport several loads of varied sizes at once and earn a more efficient income. I was amazed at the sudden difference of income just from upgrading ships. The Freighter is slower and sloppier to handle, compared to the Star Barge, but its worth it if you want to earn more credits faster as a freight captain and want to upgrade to even better freight ships.

Worth a try.

I've been playing Endless Sky for about 24 hours now and I like it, its got almost everytihng I enjoy and I hope to continue to play for hours if not day's more.

My only complaints at all is that except for in menu's everything is keyboard controlled (i've gotten used ot it and can enjoy it though) and that the keys do not default to a standard WASD movement system, While i am aware that the keys can be rebound trying to do so seems like it is not a good idea, even more so when there is no default setitngs button to reset them.

Despite this I enjoy and recommend this game to anyone who likes exploring, trading and fighting in a sci-fi environment that is quite detailed and immersive.

I've been looking for a new Escape Velocity like game for years. I absolutely adore the concept, so this was an obvious game to try.

All I can say really is, I love it. With it being open source as well, I could join in development too!

Not quite as epic as Escape Velocity, but you can tell it is made by those who really loved EV. If you want to see what games like Star Citizen should emulate, check into this. EV is a series that most PC gamers were not aware of. It launched on Mac first and did not get a PC port until the third and final game launched. The games were fantastic on their own but even better with modding. One of the most famous was the Star Wars mods which brought high detail star wars ships into EV. Endless Sky looks to be capitalizing on that. Hopefully it will have a bright future.

I wanted to put a bit more time in than some of the first impressions" reviews others have put in to see if the impression does hold up. In short: Yes! It looks like there's enough game material and enjoyment to eek out. After six hours I'm still definitely wanting more
date: and after about 4 hours into a single campaign before the story starts to get hot and saucy so it looks like there's plenty more fun to be had.\n\nThis is a simple top-down 2D space trading/exploration/RPG. All the basic concepts familiar to this genre are present: "jumping" from system to system to make your way across our galaxy (each system realistically aligned to our own galaxy and most having at least one or two planets with a short paragraph backstory) the option to either explore the galaxy and seek battle as a budding pirate hunter/pirate
recommended: flying the space equivalent of a ford transit van across the systems in comfy trading and occasional moments of absolute terror
hoursPlayed: or a hybrid mix. If for some reason you ever wanted to be a space bus conductor: there's passenger liners.\n\nI tried all three initial starter-pokemon ships but settled with the transit van for my current playthrough. in this time I have: delivered a giant space-lizard amidst a pitched fight between the navies of two factions
voteText: taken a poodle half the way across the galaxy
helpfulPercent: delivered funeral documents to grieving earther relatives
votesHelpful: and in the mean time sandwiched every bit of my hold with cargo to sell between stops. if you want something immersive to play this ticks all those boxes in even the most direly boring way to play. Picking the "interceptor" starting career immediately throws you into the slaughter.\n\nSomething over reviewers haven't covered very much here but I think is worth whetting your appetite is ship customizability: Ships are sold to you relatively complete but also have a) some empty spots and b) none of the more interesting mod cons. Take for example my light freighter I have now. I bought this thing with a loan and 500k credits to spare
votesTotal: why? Because I had plans. I made hull modifications that shrunk my cargo hold but gave me some more space to fit other things. in these things I fitted oversized turning thrusters and an improved shielding generator. Cooling vents/tubes were put in place of some spare bunk space
votesFunny: which let me switch to a beefier turret that put out just a little bit too much heat.\n\nin the real world
commentsCount: I did the equivalent of buying a beat up old lorry
column16: fitted it with armour plating and a 50.cal mounted in the passenger seat
column17: and put a v12 where there was a v8. I now had a cargo hauler that could seriously ruin a pirate's day. you know when you watch star wars and you think "I want to have my own millenium falcon?" well now you can
column18: and for free!\n\nspace trading games have been a personal passion of mine since I got my tiny 4-year old hands around a copy of Elite III.  It is a delight to play something that captures that essence of such games
column19: and to do so for free is an unexpected pleasure. Thanks Mr Zahniser. I'll look out for the next thing you make!"

reviewText: Aside from being a little confusing at first, this game is relatively quick to pick up on and easy to figure out. Earning credits to buy upgrades and ships and upgrades for those ships and hauling things from here to there to everywhere, it's kinda relaxing in some odd sort of way. Aside from having to contend with pirates, who would more seek to destroy than anything, hauling people and cargo to different locations is strangely fun. Why we can't have this going on in this day of age is beyond me, because I know I would be rich right now! Space travel must become a thing! Oh hell I'm addicted...

This is a very relaxing game to play if you want something to calm down from an AAA game release, easy to understand concept, if a slightly confuseing button layout at first. Problems you may run into are frogeting a command and needing to look it up and that fighting in game is very hard to control due to floaty movement, however it is in space so of course the movement is floaty. Also IT IS IN SPACE!

Just happened upon this game and I'm glad I did. Choose to travel the Universe as a transport, cargo freighter, or gun for hire, and build up from there. Jump from system to system mapping routes and discovering new planets to trade and take jobs on. Lots of descriptive text of the worlds and their inhabitants. I got a Star Trek" feel from this game and that is a very good thing. Totally worth checking out since it's free."

This game is a MUST HAVE! For a free game it has surprisingly good graphics and a great storyline! You start off with a small ship (Freighter, Transport or Intercepter class) and collect money from paid missions throughout the cosmos to buy a bigger ship or even a fleet of ships. I started as a trader, got a fleet reasonably fast and explored the whole main system and even went a bit further down the rabbit hole. Hopefully the developement continues.

Pros: Many systems to explore
Nice pictures and descriptions for every visitable planet/station
Player death just let's you start again, where you last docked
Following the plotline is optional
Many ships to choose from
Large freedom in playing style (conquer other ships, do escort runs, just trading only, etc.)
Cons: Difficulty is rather random (if you get mauled by a large group of hostiles, just spawn again and it is gone)
Easy to loose track of storylines
Manual control is tricky
Fixed market prices (easy for grinding, though)
These were just from the top of my head, some other points to mention are that choosing fractions is just possible by the main story line, as far as I can tell, and that the fleet commands are not really working (at least I never realized a difference between group around me and don't).

You can be a multi-millionare merchant's guild like me in the game or maybe a military anti-pirate armada. The easiest money maker for me was making simple 2 sector trade routes with feighters. Now with the big feighters, I get about 500,000 per load! All I have to say is good job to the Devs that made this game.

Do you know the kind of games where you farm resource routes to make virtual money in a very complex economy system?! And evolve with the profits you generate?!
Welcome to Endless Sky!

Honestly, the graphics (and the looong list of commands) kept me away from the game for a while. It is only after I noticed we could barely use 3 keys (J, L, M by default) and have an unexplicable amount of fun during this game.

The gameplay is very simple, but I honestly can't recommend this game enough. It's a very thrilling experience between travelling space, recruiting ships/crew, accomplishing missions, fighting/fleeing pirates, joining a clan...

What I didn't like:
- The other ships in the game are extremely random. Some planets are very calm, and one second after, they become raging with pirates and Republican resistance... Instant kills are in order!
- No real story, really. The first missions show you how to navigate and play (some sort of tutorial) and then, nothing else. Just a bunch of exploding ships...
- The ships you buy are default. No customization possible on their skins (though you can buy wepaons and stuff on them, still not accurate though since that takes up place from the merchandise too)

What kept me playing for hours now:
- Money! Money! MONEY! It's what keeps you farming circuits for hours!
- 3 keys to manage it all; some sort of pre-built autopilot for your ship.
- Reading about the planets and discovering new horizons. Each system has a planet or more with different stories. It's just amazing how much work was put in that!
- The map is EXTREMELY, I say EXTREMELY WELL OPTIMIZED!! If you get to know it, everything is shown from missions, nearby planets with their economy, destination, where you should and should not go! It's the MOST amazing map in a ES clone-game I've ever seen!
- Have a fleet, conquer space! Satisfy your ego!
- Free open-source game! It will surely improve fast!

Excellent game, that will surely improve in the upcoming months!! ;)

Originally, I really enjoyed this game.  The controls are straigtforward; there's a lot of freedom and choice; even the writing is good.  The game is also rather difficult and you die a lot.  That, in itself, is not an issue -- I like hard games.

The problem is that there is no penalty for death.  You simply restart from your last autosave... and that effectively removes all tension from the game.  Gameplay is no longer about survival, or getting rich, or being a badass fighter pilot.  It becomes a content treadmill where you grind through endless missions in order to upgrade your fleet... so that you can grind through more missions.

Even worse, death is very random and largely out of your control.  You can jump into a star system and be instantly killed by pirates.  Reload from your last autosave, jump into the same system, and there will be no pirates.  It's not like you made a bad decision (or even a risky decision) the first time; you simply moved forward, and the result was instant death.

The Game is fun. Decent Graphics, Simple Controls, Great mechanics, and a not-too-shabby 'tutorial'.
There are a few drawbacks, though. Replayability is a bit on the low side, as progression is a bit slow and you end up doing very similar missions over and over until you have a ship capable of actually fighting Pirates, which can take a while to get.
There is an occaisional bug here and there, but other than that the game runs smoothly.

Aside from the progression issues, I see potential in this game. I love how you can run out of fuel in an uninhabited sector and have to call a nearby merchant for help. I like the money system, how you can ferry goods from one place to another to earn a profit. I like how the gameplay feels, and I would love to see a Multiplayer function.

Overall, great game. Definitely worth the money... oh wait, this game is free. also a plus.

reviewText: A near identical clone of the old Escape Velocity games by Ambrosia Software; with updated and better graphics.  Everything down to the map and travel mechanics, trading, random special/story missions upon entering the spaceport (bar), ship outfitting, and even combat is taken from Escape Velocity.\n\nThis is not a bad thing.  In fact I'm happy to see an almost 20 year old game reborn into this as it remains one of my top 10 games ever.  But the best thing about it?  It's free.

Endless Sky is a freeform economic space adventure that puts you in the pilot seat of a pathetically weak ship (at first) with the promise of riches in your future. To do so, you must decide whether you will follow the law or operate outside of it. Though the economy is simple and it is very easy to find a lucrative trade route and then supplement it with jobs, the universe itself is more than alive enough to keep you engrossed.
In my time, I have had the exquisite pleasure of desperately fleeing across outer rim worlds from a vastly superior pirate fleet that refused to give up its pursuit, periously weaving my way through a system engrossed in a massive all out battle, and dogfighting a significantly better ship while my lumbering merchant ships aligned for a jump out of a losing fight.
In this time, I've also had to learn how to bum hyperdrive fuel off of other ships when I warp into a new sector only to learn there is no civilization there, abandon a crippled member of my fleet to pirates in order to ensure the survival of my remaining ships, and bribe a successful pirate not to finish my sorry self off.
Though by no means a perfect game, it is an engrossing and absolutely enjoyable experience that I recommend entirely to fans of economic sandboxes or space settings.

This game is so good that I am actually going to take the time to review it. Which I have never done before.

First of all, it is absolutely free. No in game charges, no pay to play, nothing. And somehow it is better than so many titles that I have payed for.
The game is very customizable and only requires a small amount of effort in order to mod it. I have experience in multiple coding languages so maybe I'm biased, but I found the source code very simple and user friendly. You can even create your own ships with ease! The creator encourages it and even has the game on Github for your pleasure.
The game is very casual if you want, and very intense if you want. When I started I picked a Freighter and did the merchant thing for a while. It was relaxing, carrying people and cargo back and forth for a while trying to pay off my loan, but I decided I wanted something more. So I restarted, picked an Interceptor and went out to shoot some pirates. The point is you can make the game what you want. It can be hard, easy, fast, slow, up, down, left, right, start, select, anything!
The story is very engaging! Currently there is only one storyline you can play through (The Free Worlds), but I'll be damned if that wasn't one of the best stories I have ever played. I felt connected to Freya, Katya, and Ijs, when I fought with my fleet I cared about them and each ship lost was like a knife in my heart, I had let my comrades down.
The world feels very active and busy, kind of like an Elder Scrolls game. Very rarely are things just standing around doing nothing.

I have only two problems with the game right now. The first is that sometimes there are game breaking glitches, such as when attempting to board a ship my screen would go black and I could no longer interact with anything, or when I sell the ship I'm currently piloting, but have one parked offworld and I am immediately sent to that ship.
The other problem I have is... There isn't enough! I want more! I want more Katya, I want to see Raven again, I want to learn about the Korath and the Quarg, I want to build more ships like the Dreadnought and the Kestrel, and I especially want to fight more Alphas.

This game gets a 10/10 from me and I would gladly pay money for it were it not free.

On a  more serious note this is one of those games that us nostalgia hunters were looking for.  As seen in the descritpion this is a spirtual sucessor of sorts to Ambrosia's Escape Velocity, and Escapre Velocity override, optimized for what gamers expect as the basics of more modern game.  Trade, bounty hunt, or shuttle folks around to make your living.  As you progress you can start to decide how youll want to proceed. Want a bigger freighter?  Go get it!  Want to be an unstoppable pirate disabling ships, stripping them down for parts?  Yes you can.  Hiring escorts can be expensive, but definatly cheaper than buying a new ship and starting over.  Its minimalistic but thats all part of its charm.  Absolutley recomend to first time players and those who remember that glory days of simple yet in depth games.

The Game is fun. Decent Graphics, Simple Controls, Great mechanics, and a not-too-shabby 'tutorial'.
There are a few drawbacks, though. Replayability is a bit on the low side, as progression is a bit slow and you end up doing very similar missions over and over until you have a ship capable of actually fighting Pirates, which can take a while to get.
There is an occaisional bug here and there, but other than that the game runs smoothly.

Aside from the progression issues, I see potential in this game. I love how you can run out of fuel in an uninhabited sector and have to call a nearby merchant for help. I like the money system, how you can ferry goods from one place to another to earn a profit. I like how the gameplay feels, and I would love to see a Multiplayer function.

Overall, great game. Definitely worth the money... oh wait, this game is free. also a plus.

The game is very similar to the Escape Velocity games, and that is a good thing. It has most of the features I loved about the EV series like; capturing ships and adding them to your fleet, open world exploration, RPG optimizing weapons and shielding, NPC factions that will attack if provoked and are governed by your reputation to them, and much more. Those are all the things I believe is what makes it so much fun.
There are only a few things I do not like about it and that is; some of the functions like item search oversimplify the game and prove counter productive, in that it makes it too easy to find the item you want rather than exploring the galaxy to find it. It is convenient but it shortens the end game. What I mean is I have only played a few hours and already have millions of credits with no hacks. All the items are shown, I just have to select one and it shows me where it can be found. To me, that is boring, I like exploring and finding new things. Finding a black market item that is not sold anywhere else and is better than the available items, is like finding gold. Sadly I doubt this game has a black market since all items are shown.

The positives outweigh the negatives, you should try it. :)

This game is actually really cool. It is completely free to play, no bogus with paying for in game content, so absolutely everything is free. You get to fly around a pretty cool galaxy, with lots of different types of things you can do, each of which gets you money, which  then allows you to do fun things like upgrade your ship or outright buy a new one. The one thing I was worried about when i started, was that there would be tons of ships just acting as pirates, going around killing the newer players with weaker ships, but so far i have only died to pirates a couple times, and it largely happens when I am intenionally scouting out areas rich in pirate activity, so its pretty easy to avoid for the most part, since so long as you have enough fuel you can just warp away. Overall a pretty fun experience, so I'd give it an 8/10, only taking off some points because its not exactly visuall stimulating, and because there is no real story besides, get as much money as possible and upgrade the living hell out of your ship. But since its entirely free, and a really small download, you may as well give it a shot.
Menu interface could need a bit of improvement.\nHaving to call out starmap and click every time you want to jump is quite annoying.

Definitly a great game, There are a multitude of ships, ranging from merchant to Militant. The Encounters with Pirates are almost always fun (Only bad if you die from an armada of Pirates near spawn zone), The story (What i could figure out how to do) is very interesting, and best of all there's ton more updates on the way. It may be unfinished and in need of a few changes but it's F2P and is still in beta so give it some time and it will be an amazing game (More-so than it is already). I give it an 10/10, because it's not finished, but I still play it more than i play Fallout 4.

This game is a real delight. It is basically EV Nova, but with many minor improvements that make gameplay more enjoyable--for example, by accessing the map while in a starport, you can see what the prices of trade goods are in other systems. No more scouring the internet for trade guides or taking notes on prices yourself!\n\nPlus, it's free, with no Captain Hector out to destroy you after 30 days!
10/10 Good game

I have always been a fan of games thaty involve space and traveling around and needing to think about what your doing. This game hits that right on the mark, This game takes a sort of FTL style and makes it so you have to either fight to survive or make good decisions and know what kind of recources wherever your going is going to need. Basically in this game you can either become a pirate hunter or pirate yourself and kill ships, board them and take their loot. Or you can go the more safer" route and do trade routes and bring tourists places. For trading you can take jobs to bring tons of goods to certain planets or the same with tourists
date: You can also buy goods at a planet and bring the goods to another planet and sell the goods for a profit. All the while you are saving money to upgrade your ship or buy new ships. At the beginning of the game you take out a loan to buy your first ship and throughout the first year of the game you must pay off your loan. Events happen in thew game like civil war and special missions. Overall this game is very fun and if you like space sims or anything of the same you should try this game out. Plus its free so why not =] PS. i recommend going with trading and jobs instead of pirating first off because its a lot easier. Also i would easily pay $10+ for this game."

Pretty fun game but has some serious glitches that I'm sure is losing the developer some fan base. I had a wasp fighter get shot down, and upon reloading from the last planet as the game instructs my screen freezes on that same wasp fighter and makes it my flagship whenever I pass through that system so I lose control of whatever fleet I bring through.  I also lose whatever credits I spent purchasing newer ships as they somehow get stuck in that system as well and don't show up in my fleet when I reload. With no real tutorial that I've seen, the storyline quests can be pretty dumb and time consuming so essentially you just wind up cruising the stars hoping to earn enough credits to buy bigger and better ships. Not bad, a good time killer but that's about it - good thing it's free because it would be a joke if you had to spend any money on it. Check it out, and don't laugh too hard at the game developers.

This game reminds me of the good old days of playing that Starfighter game and all i can say right now is that i have high expectations for this game and its game developer. This game has so much potential to be such a great game. Let's give this game some time and see how this game progress from here on out. At the moment, this game needs some new content like new titles for the faction you're in for like bragging rights? Maybe perhaps allow the raiding and protecting of the space stations and colonies? Another way to secure an income for cash like mining minerals in space and selling them at the marketplace in planets? I would love some achievements too if it is not too much to ask for. An AI enemy would be nice too like an enigmatic alien race pillaging and raiding for some unknown motive could be foreshadowing for some really awesome storyline! Even a unsophisticated stats screen would be nice to monitor progress/progression. Documenting this game in its early stages is one of life's simplest pleasures that i derive from. Thank you for reading this rather long review and have a nice day! Heck, go have a nice week instead~!

Endless Sky is a completely free, top-down, 2D space game. But there's more to it than that; think Elite Dangerous meets 2D with text-based story telling charm.

Gameplay:

Gameplay typically goes along the lines of this:
Game: Buy your first ever spacecraft! Pick from a transport

if you like Escape velocity, this is basically it. im pretty thrilled about it. i hated that EV games just kind of lingered and disappeared. this is the same idea, but it looks nicer, and it has gameplay improvements over EV Nova. jumps don't require moving away from planets as that is just a time hog, and auto pilots will assist your landing to make things less frustrating. the map could be bigger, and as mods are made for it, im sure it will become the community game it should be. i think you are gonna love it, and you can't beat free. you don't like their free game? thats your fault not theirs. they give and you just take, like a filthy horse person. just give it a try. you'll see its as good as you could possibly hope for, and likely to get better once the community gets its hands on it. hell i already made my own mod with 2 new planets, it took me like 30 minutes. more dedicated people will likely whip up a full star wars mod in like 2 weeks, by just converting the images and scripts from the EV mods.

This game is very well made, but the gameplay can be difficult, and the tutorials are a little confusing. Overall, I recomend this game to any person interested in space age rpg's. The story is well written from what I have managed to see so far, I would rate this a solid 7/10.
Hallelujah, Escape Velocity is back! I can't wait to see where this game goes with contributions, but it's already a pretty solid follow-up to one of my favorite series of all time.
